There are several possible answers to this.   The standard cosmological answer is the energy was created in the very first instance of the universe by a quantum vacuum fluctuation.    It is actually imprecise to say energy cannot be created or destroyed it happens all the time.   The equation that governs this is: ΔEΔt≥ℏ2 What this equation tells you is the shorter the time period you look at the less certain you can be about the energy in the system.   But you can always be certain there is some energy in any system. Over long periods this you can be extremely certain in the amount of energy, so the principle energy cannot be created or destroy holds up.  But when people talk about quantum vacuum fluctuations, or and electron-positron pair appearing in a vacuum this is exactly the equation that they are referring to. Now this is not a fully satisfying answer, as the universe always demands repayment of this energy loan.   Even extreme cases, like say an electron-positron pair appear near the event horizon, one is swallowed and one escape.   It seems like "repayment" of the loan is impossible.   But this process known as Hawking radiation can actually take energy from inside the event horizon of a black hole to maintain conservation of energy. So how exactly can we have a whole universe of energy, and not have had the debt repaid?   There are two possible response.   One is to say it came from thermal energy.   Which is basically a self referencing answer.  Essentially the energy was always there, it just changed forms.   Another is to say there is a net zero energy. The net zero energy is more interesting.   Both gravity and electro-static force have a negative potential energy associated with them.   This means if lets say the only thing you had in the universe where two neutrinos.  (The lightest particle we know of.)   If you brought those neutrinos infinitely close together you would have an infinite amount of energy.    What this means is if at the start of the universe just two particles where borrowed with no net energy and they were brought together into a singularity, without mutual annihilation there could be enough energy for a full universe. So it turns out obtaining infinite energy to power a universe is not hard to come up with.   The hard part is actually trying to figure out the laws of nature that prevents this from happening again.   General relativity tells us something very similar happens in a black hole when a singularity is formed.   Fortunately though, we are protected from such an event by an event horizon.

There are a number of problems with this question. First our ability to explain where the energy came from or not isn’t positive evidence for “god did it”. To illustrate I could say “If homosexual universe creating pixies didn’t exist, where did all the energy come from, since energy can neither be created nor be destroyed?”To which you might say “homosexual universe creating pixies aren’t real” to which I’d point out that there is the same amount of non fallacious argument for their existence as there is for any gods from what I’ve been presented. Next problem is you seem to be trying to use the The first law of thermodynamics, also known as Law of Conservation of Energy. But you seem to not understand what it actually says. It states states that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant; it is said to be conserved over time. Now there are two problems for you. First is we don’t know if the universe is an isolated system. We know that the visible universe is not an isolated system. So even at that scale your premise is wrong. So you’ve mangled a scientific concept then pulled an argument from ignorance fallacy, specifically a god of the gaps fallacy. That since you can’t think of how something happened and no believe if no one else can then your answer of “god did it” wins by default. This is bad logic. Even if I have no answer to your question your answer doesn’t become more correct. For example if I ask two five year old children what the cube root of 27 is and one says “5” and the other says “I don’t know” the child that said “5” isn’t more likely to be right because the other child was honest and said “I don’t know”. The positive energy of particles is exactly in balance with negative gravitational energy. Total energy in the universe is zero. I addressed this on a prior Quora post: Stephen Hawking said the total energy of the universe is zero and Brian Greene said we still have to account for 10 kg before inflation. Who is right? Here’s where the idea of zero energy comes from:  https://www.astrosociety.org/publication/a-universe-from-nothing/ “…In the inflationary theory, matter, antimatter, and photons were produced by the energy of the false vacuum, which was released following the phase transition. All of these particles consist of positive energy. This energy, however, is exactly balanced by the negative gravitational energy of everything pulling on everything else. In other words, the total energy of the universe is zero! It is remarkable that the universe consists of essentially nothing, but (fortunately for us) in positive and negative parts. You can easily see that gravity is associated with negative energy: If you drop a ball from rest (defined to be a state of zero energy), it gains energy of motion (kinetic energy) as it falls. But this gain is exactly balanced by a larger negative gravitational energy as it comes closer to Earth’s center, so the sum of the two energies remains zero…. The idea of a zero-energy universe, together with inflation, suggests that all one needs is just a tiny bit of energy to get the whole thing started (that is, a tiny volume of energy in which inflation can begin). The universe then experiences inflationary expansion, but without creating net energy.” Brian Greene is pointing out that 10 kg (a tiny bit of energy) is needed to get the whole thing started. “….Quantum theory, and specifically Heisenberg’s uncertainty principle, provide a natural explanation for how that energy may have come out of nothing. Throughout the universe, particles and antiparticles spontaneously form and quickly annihilate each other without violating the law of energy conservation. These spontaneous births and deaths of so-called “virtual particle” pairs are known as “quantum fluctuations.” Indeed, laboratory experiments have proven that quantum fluctuations occur everywhere, all the time. Virtual particle pairs (such as electrons and positrons) directly affect the energy levels of atoms, and the predicted energy levels disagree with the experimentally measured levels unless quantum fluctuations are taken into account. Perhaps many quantum fluctuations occurred before the birth of our universe. Most of them quickly disappeared. But one lived sufficiently long and had the right conditions for inflation to have been initiated. Thereafter, the original tiny volume inflated by an enormous factor, and our macroscopic universe was born. The original particle-antiparticle pair (or pairs) may have subsequently annihilated each other – but even if they didn’t, the violation of energy conservation would be minuscule, not large enough to be measurable.”

I feel I still haven't answered your question, so coming back at it what you are probably asking is what exactly happened at Planck epoch and how did we end up with something such as the Inflation (cosmology) . All ideas concerning the very early universe (cosmogony) are speculative. No accelerator experiments have yet probed energies of sufficient magnitude to provide any experimental insight into the behavior of matter at the energy levels that prevailed during this period. Proposed scenarios differ radically. Some examples are the Hartle–Hawking initial state, string landscape, brane inflation, string gas cosmology, and the ekpyrotic universe. Some of these are mutually compatible, while others are not.The Planck epoch is an era in traditional (non-inflationary) big bang cosmology wherein the temperature was so high that the four fundamental forces—electromagnetism, gravitation, weak nuclear interaction, and strong nuclear interaction—were one fundamental force. Little is understood about physics at this temperature; different hypotheses propose different scenarios. Traditional big bang cosmology predicts a gravitational singularity before this time, but this theory relies on general relativity and is expected to break down due to quantum effects. Why would you think that it had to “come from” somewhere else? Seriously. If it came from somewhere else, then where did that somewhere else come from? And then where did that somewhere else come from? Etc ad infinitum. It’s called infinite regress and it’s a logical absurdity. At some point you have resort to the old Special Pleading Fallacy to escape it and then people who know how to think will mock you for cheating. We need to give up on this ridiculous notion that at some point in the distant past there was “nothingness” and that everything that exists sprang into existence from nothingness. The evidence doesn’t support that notion and it leads to a complete breakdown of logic. And no, the big bang model noes not posit the universe springing into existence from nothing. In fact, it posits the exact opposite. It posits that everything in the observable universe was in pretty much the exact same place at the same time about 13.8 billion years ago, making that “everything” nearly infinitely dense, hot, and small. But it was still everything, not nothing. The question, as posed, is fundamentally meaningless. If energy cannot be created or destroyed, then by definition it couldn’t have “come from” anyplace, because by definition it must have always existed and must continue to exist, in one form or another, forever. If you want to make it have “come from” someplace from “nothingness”, then you’ll have to change the definition of energy to allow it to be created and/or destroyed. You can’t have it both ways.

Conservation of energy says that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. One form of energy can be transformed to another and this is what keeps the Universe going. Lets take the example of fossil fuel. Energy is stored in bonds between the atoms of hydrocarbons in fossil fuel which when broken by applying heat energy releases a *lot more* heat energy that is tapped to perform useful work. Fossil fuel is derived from fossilized remains of prehistoric organisms which derived their life-giving energy either directly or indirectly from the Sun. The Sun derives all its energy from fusing hydrogen into helium inside its core. The energy of the hydrogen atoms (forming our Sun and other such stars) derived their energy when they were created from bare subatomic particles (protons and electrons) at the time of nucleosynthesis around 300,000 years after the Big Bang. All the protons and electrons in the Universe were created moments after the Big Bang, before which time there was basically a primordial soup of particles with higher and higher energies. As we inch still closer in time to the Big Bang a point is reached, the Planck epoch (10^-43 s), beyond which standard physical laws break. So we see that the energy that is stored in fossil fuels can ultimately to traced back to the energy of the Big Bang. This primordial energy has undergone many transformations in the 13.5 billion years that it has been around and ultimately driving human civilisation forward.

Many fundamentals aspects of the universe can currently be honestly answered with: "we don't know". And it's good to be able to say that. It flags the area as being a mystery for further inquiry and research. What we don't do is eschew the honest, "we don't know" to the assumption, "well it MUST be god then!" Consider, at every point in human history, there were natural phenomona that was beyond us - that eluded our ability to understand and explain at that point in time. There was a time when we didn't understand lighting and thunder or the stars or fire etc etc etc. Usually in the past, when such explanations were beyond us, we assigned the mystery to god. How does lightning work? god! How do the stars stay in the sky? god! But over and over again, those things that were attributed to god were eventually understood and explained as a part of the natural world. That's the mistake. To assign everything that we currently don't understand to god because we're uncomfortable, for some reason, with having to admit that 1. at this time, we don't know and 2. there may come a time in the future that we WILL 3. it may indeed be a possibility that for some things, we will NEVER know. But we still feel a need to attribute the unknown to god(s). With millennia of history under our belts, you'd figure that human beings would have learned by now not to do this - to attribute to god what we currently don't understand. But as your question indicates, that impulse is still strong. As it is with other current mysteries like the origin of life (from non living compounds to living organisms) or the nature of death and the soul and of course, the ultimate origin of everything up to and including the big bang. But note that "because god" cuts off inquiry. In lieu of a natural explanation, we chalk it up to the ineffable and call it a day. "We don't know" leaves open the door and extends an invitation to find out. And it is THAT avenue that has brought us from hunter gatherers to advanced, technological civilization. "We don't know". Know it. Love it.

Nobody did. But that is another matter. The concept of energy is not a primary one, as is often imagined. From basic unit analysis you will notice that its unit, the Joule, is derived. Displacement = m Displacement over time = Speed = m/s Acceleration = change of speed = (m/s)/s = m/s ^2 Force = a mass Accelerating = Kg x m/s^2 = kg.m/s^2 Energy = a Force exerted over a distance = m x kg.m/s^2 = kg.m^2/s^2 (the Joule) So the classically defined idea of energy isn't meaningful without Distance (space), Time and Mass. For electromagnetic energy this still holds because Planck's constant is required and defined as 6.62607004 × 10 to the power of -34 kg.m^2 / s Multiply in the time component of frequency (hertz) 1/s and you get kg.m^2/s^2 So energy is is a derived property. What bothers you is conservation of energy. At the very smallest scales this conservation rule gets more flexible and probabilistic, but it doesn't add up to much more than Quantum fluctuation If time, space and mass are emergent properties of quantum fields, rather than absolute conditions, then the question of the origin of energy goes down a deep rabbit hole that nobody has been to the bottom of... yet. There are many different attempts going on right now, but science is naturally slow, so hang in there, if you are young now, you might see this one answered one day.

Our universe is what we know as a closed-system. A closed-system is something in physics that doesn't exchange matter with the rest of what is our there (other possible universes or "systems" occupying space/time on the space-time continuum). But our universe was not always this way. Before the Big-Bang, what ever was there in seemingly nothingness were these random particles called tachyons. There is no confirmed existence of them but are like pure forms of neutrinos which bear some resemblance with the peculiar properties of tachyons. Tachyons always travel faster than the speed of light (try to forget Einstein for a moment) and have an imaginary amount of mass. Since they break the rules of regular matter and because there was no closed system in play matter and energy get created and destroyed. These tachyons would pop up and disappear in the measure of Plank Time. The last thing in place is a false vacuum and a true vacuum. A false vacuum is a state of high-energy where the tachyons are unstable. Ideally they would want to go to a lower-energy state. Think of it as a dam holding water back. You would think that the water is at a low-energy state until a crack in the dam shows you that the water will flow out and settle in a massive puddle. That is the transition from a high-energy to a low-energy state. It is also described as the natural or ground-state. Similar thing happens with tachyons, except a crack in the dam or a rip in this emptiness that represents the true-vacuum or space-time continuum. At this point the water or the energy (which is a real number) inside the tachyon wants to immediately transition into the ground-state or lower-energy state and so the water flows out faster and may make a bigger crack in the dam. In this case, the dam is the empty area before the universe. The crack reveals the true vacuum or evolving space-time continuum for the universe. Suddenly the crack becomes bigger into a bubble and expands as actual matter and energy on the inside of the bubble. The outside of the bubble is still covered in decaying tachyons as this immensely hot and energetic bubble of expanding matter and energy is theorized to be the Big Bang as we know it. Cosmic Inflation and the universe began then as a closed system. So even though matter and energy are never created or destroyed, they came from the following: an open system, tachyons, emptiness, false vacuums and bubbles of space-time continuum/matter/energy in true vacuums. These conditions are ultimately a theoretic explanation for the birth of our universe.

There is a very simple answer to this question but you will probably not like it very much and you will feel that it doesn't actually answers anything. Fact 1: The law of conservation of energy i.e. that energy cannot be created or destroyed is closely tied to symmetry of time, i.e. things are roughly the same today as it was yesterday in the sense that any experiment you did yesterday will yield roughly the same result today. If there is probabilistic or chance involved, both results will be within the same a priori probability of the experiment and if there is no probability or chance involved, it will always yield exactly the same result regardless of when you do it. Under these conditions AND ONLY under these conditions do the law of conservation of energy hold. What this means is that if you posit a time that is unlike any other time in that it is the beginning of time, then there is no symmetry of time near that time. Consequently, there is no reason to assume that the law of conservation of energy apply to that time. Compare the situation to the law of conservation of momentum if you are nearby a wall that prevent objects from passing it. The law of momentum will not hold. A ball hitting that wall will change its momentum and suddenly fly in the opposite direction. The conservation of momentum is not valid in that situation - well you can argue that the momentum is still preserved when you consider the minute fluctuation of the atoms of the wall which heats up a tiny bit from the impact and in the same way you can argue that the law of conservation of energy may hold up through a big bang if you could somehow follow each individual piece through the big bang - but that's exactly the point - the big bang is a singularity, you cannot follow each individual particle through the big bang. We know nothing about the state of the particle even at 10^-37 seconds after big bang, it is too short time after the big bang for us to know anything about it, much less anything before - whatever that is supposed to mean - the time of big bang. So, no we cannot assume that the law of conservation of energy is valid at the time of big bang. That would just be silly. So the answer to your question is: There is no rule that say that energy cannot be created or destroyed at that time in history. The law of conservation of energy only applies to situations where you have symmetry of time and that also means that it must be a closed system but closed system is not enough - it is the symmetry of time that is the necessary and sufficient condition for the law of conservation of energy to apply. A closed system does not have symmetry of time because if you add energy to the system doing the experiment at an earlier time when the energy was lower may yield a different result than if you do it at a later time when energy is higher. Reverse if you remove energy from the system instead of adding to it.

That leaves the field wide open for theories and conjectures on what other forms energy can become that perhaps we don’t know everything about, or forms we do not know anything about because they have yet to be observed.

We haven't developed a theory that explains the origin of energy yet.  However, current theory and measurements are converging on a strange idea about energy that may simplify the origin greatly without completely explaining it. When cosmologists use the General Theory of Relativity with quantum mechanics to describe possible evolutions of the observable universe, they find that if the total energy (this takes into account that mass is equivalent to energy) of the universe is a little greater than zero, the universe would have collapsed shortly after forming.  OTOH, if the total energy is a little less than zero (gravitational energy is inherently negative), no structures would likely have formed.  The evolution of the universe works most simply if the total energy is and always was zero.  This is sometimes referred to as the ultimate free lunch. Estimates of mass in the universe at first indicated that there wasn't nearly enough mass to make the total energy zero.  Then dark matter was discovered, but things still didn't quite work.  With the discovery of dark energy, even without knowing what it is, the total estimated energy in the observable universe came out very close to zero.  Theory and measurement seem to agree on this crazy result. See: What's the Total Energy In the Universe?

Energy can also travel in the form of electromagnetic waves, such as heat, light, radio, and gamma rays. Your body is using metabolic energy from our last meal as you read this. Energy is constantly flowing and changing form. If you take your metabolic energy and rub your hands together, you have made metabolic energy into mechanical energy. Your hands will heat up. That is some of the mechanical energy turning into heat energy. So energy can change form, but where did that energy ultimately come from? Let say that a bicycle is rolling down the hill, transferring potential energy into kinetic energy. The bicycle got its potential energy by the rider using metabolic energy to move the pedals. The pedals used mechanical energy to move the chain, which moved the wheels. The rider's metabolic energy came from chemical energy that was stored in the molecules of the food she ate. That chemical energy entered the animal whose meat she ate by the animal digesting a plant and breaking the bonds in its molecules. The plant made the molecules by using light energy from the Sun. The Sun's light energy came from electrons in its atoms lowering energy states, and releasing energy. The energy in the atoms came from the nuclear reactions in the heart of the Sun. And scientists say that the nuclear reaction is started from Big Bang. So the short answer is that the energy we encounter and use everyday has always been with us since the beginning of the universe and always will be with us. It just changes form all around us. That is called the law of conservation of energy.

The first law of thermodynamics doesn't actually specify that matter can neither be created nor destroyed, but instead that the total amount of energy in a closed system cannot be created nor destroyed (though it can be changed from one form to another). It was after nuclear physics told us that mass and energy are essentially equivalent, this is what Einstein meant when he wrote E=mc^2 - that we realized the 1st law of thermodynamics also applied to mass. Mass became another form of energy that had to be included in a thorough thermodynamic treatment of a system. The first thing we have to do is determine what a "closed system" is, when we look at a physical situation and draw an imaginary circle around it, we're defining a system. A refrigerator, for example, can be a thermodynamical system. But once we've specified that the system is closed, it means that everything inside the system at that moment, the total amount of energy, be it potential energy (mass can be thought of as a kind of potential energy) or kinetic energy or both must stay at that same constant level. If the amount goes up or down, either the system isn't closed, or we've neglected to account for energy (for instance, heat) coming into the system or leaving the system. If we draw our imaginary circle around the universe, we can call the universe a closed system, but it means the total amount of energy in the universe has to remain the same from its beginning until now.

It’s a common misunderstanding to assert that religion and science are incompatible, or that one “disproves” the other based on what you believe in. Despite not identifying as religious myself, I’ve never bought into this assertion. Science is limited in what it can answer. Broadly speaking, it strives to explain the “how” and “what” questions. How does X happen?How long ago did X happen?How can we justify our belief that X happened or that X will happen?What are the physical constants of the universe?Religion tackles more of the philosophical “why” questions. Why are the physical constants what they are?Why does the universe have the amount of energy/mass it does?Why does the universe behave according to the laws as we understand them?You start getting in trouble when you use the wrong tool to answer your questions. “How old is the earth?” is a question better asked of science. We have good ways of measuring it. Adding up the ages of the characters in the bible and back-tracing it to the start of Genesis is a foolish way of answering this question. Likewise, trying to devise an experiment to answer why the physical constants are what they are is an impossible task. We can measure what they are, but how do you measure “why they are that” and not something else? Maybe they were made that way by someone or something that knew what would arise. Maybe it’s just a coincidence. This question is one that does not lend itself to a scientific answer. “I don’t know” is the best I think we can do—at least right now.

We know that much of our energy originated in stars including the sun. But where or what produces the star’s energy? Surprise, it’s nuclear fusion energy. Actually, this means that the mass that is converted into the sunlight, for example, must therefore also be a form of energy. So, to be accurate, we must say that mass and energy are each conserved only if we take into account that mass has an energy equivalent or that energy has a mass equivalent. Conservation of energy - Wikipedia conservation of energy (total, including material or rest energy), and conservation of mass (total, not just rest), each still holds as an (equivalent) law. In the 18th century, these had appeared as two seemingly-distinct laws. In other words, the sunlight comes from some mass of hydrogen that is converted to electromagnetic energy in the fusion process. The hydrogen consumed is also converted into very hot helium which has both a rest mass and a mass equivalent to the thermal motion of the helium atoms.

If energy cannot be created or destroyed, where did it come from? Energy and matter are aspects of the universe and are interchangeable. But it’s curious that we insist that everything must have ‘come from’ something else. There is, in fact, no evidence to lead us to think that the universe or anything in it - energy/matter and time - were the product of something else. We are used to the fact that everything we can handle has been created out of something else. Our house has been created by a creator - us - from bricks and mortar, the bricks created in a kiln, and so on. Our planet has been created through the physical accumulation of its constituents out of interstellar dust. We have been created through the fertilisation of cells, followed by the addition of energy and nutrients. The creation concept is so ingrained that we simply can't envisage the possibility that the universe itself might not have been created at all. How about, ‘the universe exists and that is all we can know.’

There is no need for someone to have created energy, since one can make a plausible argument that the energy of the universe is zero. This issue is still debated among physicists, and I would say there is no consensus, but the argument in favor of zero is that in a semi-classical calculation, the mass energy mc2 is exactly cancelled by the negative gravitational binding energy of the mass to the universe. We see apparent energy because the binding energy is constant, but the form of the positive component can change (rest mass, kinetic energy, local potential energy, etc.). This has a nice philosophical touch, because it implies that the creation of the universe took no energy. But, I emphasize, this is based on a semi-classical argument. There are theorists who make arguments (that may be right) that the total energy of the universe cannot be defined in any meaningful way. I think that is currently correct, but I suspect that some future physicist will work a way around the objections, and so we will conclude that the total energy of the universe is indeed zero. But that’s speculation.

We can raise precisely the same objection against the materialists and ask them, "If we follow the chain of causality back, we will ultimately reach the primary cause. Let us say that cause is not God, but matter/energy. Tell us who created primary matter/energy. You who believe in the law of causality, answer us: if matter/energy is the ultimate cause of all things, what is the cause of matter/energy? You say that the source of all phenomena is matter-energy; what is the cause and origin of matter-energy?" Since the chain of causality cannot recede into infinity, they can answer only that matter is an eternal and timeless entity for which no beginning can be posited: matter is non-created, has no beginning or end, and its being arises from within its own nature. This means that the materialists accept the principle of eternity and non-origination; they believe that all things arose out of eternal matter and that being arises from within the very nature of matter, without any need for a creator. Russell openly states this belief in the lecture quoted above. He says: "There is no proof that the world ever had a beginning. The idea that things must once have had a beginning results from the poverty of our imagination."4 In just the same way that Russell regards matter as eternal, believers in God attribute eternity to God. Belief in an eternal being is then common to materialist and religious philosophers: both groups agree that there is a primary cause, but believers in God regard the primary cause as wise, all-knowing, and possessing the power of decision and will, whereas in the view of the materialists, the primary cause has neither consciousness, intelligence, perception, nor the power of decision. Thus, the removal of God in no way solves the problem posed by eternal being. Moreover, matter is the locus for motion and change, and its motion is dynamic and situated within its own essence. Now, essential motion is incompatible with eternity, and matter and essential stability are two mutually exclusive categories that cannot be fused in a single locus. Whatever is stable and immutable in its essence cannot accept movement and change within that essence. How do Marxists, who believe that matter is accompanied by its antithesis, justify the eternity of matter/energy? Eternity means stability and immutability of essence, the impossibility of cessation, but matter is in its essence a compendium of forces and potentialities; it is relativity itself, totally caught up in living and dying. Eternity is incompatible with the mode of being possessed by matter and the factors and attributes necessitated by its nature. The belief of those who have faith in God concerning a fixed and absolute principle relates to a being who in and of his nature can accept stability and absoluteness; his nature is completely devoid of and remote from the properties of matter. The very nature of matter refuses permanence, eternity and continuity, for it can never separate itself from movement, relativity, and it stands in opposition to being a prime or absolute agent. It will be useful here to relate the discussion of Imam as-Sadiq, upon whom be peace, with one of the materialists of his age. The materialist: "Out of what were beings created?" The Imam: "They were created out of nothing (i.e., they were originally non-beings)." The materialist: "How do they grow and emerge from nonbeing?" The Imam: "Did I not say that all things in the world were created out of nothing? My purport is this, that all beings were originally non-beings; they were non-existent, and then they became existent. You wish to say that the world is eternal, but this notion is incorrect for the following reasons: "First, if the material world is eternal, it follows that an eternal being should be subject to change and cessation, which is impossible. "Second, if the elements comprising the world are eternal by virtue of their essence, how is it possible that they should enter the embrace of death and disappearance? And if, conversely, they lack life in their essences, how can life surge forth from them? "If you say that living beings emerge from living elements and inanimate beings from inanimate elements, we reply that an essence that lacks life in and of itself cannot be eternal and cannot be the source for life." The materialist: "If matter/energy is as you say, why are beings said to be eternal?" The Imam: "Belief in the eternity of the universe is held by those who deny the existence of a ruler and planner of creation, reject the messengers of God, regard the books they bring as the fables of the ancients, and concoct beliefs pleasing to themselves."5 URL Lesson 6: The Need of the World for One Without Need

The law of conservation of energy comes from the symmetry of time, according to Nöther’s theorem. It arises because if you do something today, and do exactly the same tomorrow, you expect exactly the same outcome. The problem then is, if you assume the Universe came out of nothing, there was no time symmetry then. Before the Big Bang, there was not even time (according to one theory). Of course it all might have been there anyway, if you follow the “Big Bounce” theory. My view is that since we don’t know what happened, we can’t answer this question, but if a point was created, leaving aside near infinite negative gravitational energy to counter the positive energy of the bang, we cannot answer because time was not symmetric about the point, and hence the conservation law does not apply.

The original law of conservation of energy dates to the Enlightenment, being formulated by scientists such as Galileo, Huygens and Newton. It was foundational to classical physics from about 1650 to about 1900. It was disproved in Einstein’s famous 1905 Special Theory of Relativity, which proposed that energy can be created from matter. The law was updated to require conservation of energy plus matter in a closed system. More recently, scientists have managed to extract matter-antimatter particle pairs from a vacuum, which appears to upset the apple-cart once again. Theoretical breakthrough: Generating matter and antimatter from nothing. But the most fundamental underlying problem in this question has nothing to do with matter, energy or physics. It is simply, Why is there anything at all, instead of nothing?

This is a highly paradoxical question which cannot be answered so easily. But however if we consider that somehow this energy was here from the start, there is an interesting theory of ekpyrotic universe. This theory says that the universe was born not just once, but multiple times in endless cycles of death and rebirth. Enormous sheet-like "branes" representing different parts of our universe, collide about once every trillion years, triggering Big Bang-like explosions that re-inject matter and energy into the universe. The brains behind this theory are  Steinhardt and Neil Turok. At Cambridge university this duo provided an alternative to Big Bang theory claiming that their theory will explain not only inflation but mysteries of dark energy and dark matter as well. If this theory is true then we can proudly say that universe is ageless and self-renewing. Matter does indeed get created from nothing, as long as an equal amount of antimatter is created at the same time. The vacuum of empty space is actually seething with quantum activity. Particles and antiparticles are constantly appearing from nothing and then recombining into nothing. This is a consequence of quantum mechanics, one of the most successful predictive theories of all time. It be measured in the lab as the Casimir effect. It is the basis of Steven Hawking's theory on black hole evaporation: black holes can separate the ephemeral particle pairs so that the matter escapes but the antimatter falls in and reduces the mass of the black hole. The probability that a particle will spontaneously appear falls off rapidly with particle size. The probability of a mass the size of the universe appearing is incredibly low (maybe biggest understatement of all time), but is nonzero. But maybe the probability is 1 and we just don't know why yet. We have yet to figure out what dark matter and energy are, and where the rest of the antimatter is so that the net mass of the universe is zero.

You misunderstand the laws of thermodynamics. The statement that energy cannot be created nor destroyed refers explicitly to within a closed system within our own universe.
